awd_titl_txt: Rift dynamics and primate evolution at the close of the Paleogene: A view from the Rukwa Rift Basin
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a paleontological investigation to understand how primates and other organisms responded to dramatic environmental changes approximately 25 million years ago in Africa. The primary goals are to characterize a newly discovered fauna, find additional fossil-bearing localities, and conduct geological analyses to document the precise age and environmental setting for each locality. Fossils from this critically under-sampled temporal and geographic setting, including some of the earliest evidence of ape species, fill a gap in the evolutionary record and make it possible to test hypotheses regarding the sequence, timing and ecological context of primate evolution and biotic transitions. The project includes an interdisciplinary research team to mentor early-career scientists and provide hands-on field and laboratory research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including females and students from underrepresented groups in STEM research. Results will be disseminated via conference presentations and publications in international journals, seminars for general audiences, symposia/workshops, interactive science outreach websites, museum exhibits, and K-12 learning activities.

The study area for this project records an important window into Late Oligocene African terrestrial ecosystems, yielding the oldest specimens documenting the cercopithecoid-hominoid divergence. Near the Oligo-Miocene boundary, collision between Afro-Arabia and Eurasia resulted in large-scale faunal turnover, with eventual replacement of much of Africa's resident biota by invasive species. This altered the landscape of predation and competition, with profound implications for biodiversity. This project hypothesizes that key shifts in primate community composition were already occurring on the African continent prior to the Oligo-Miocene transition. Recent discoveries suggest that early hominoid and cercopithecoid evolution in eastern Africa took place against the backdrop of previously unrecognized tectonic activity in the western branch of the East African Rift System, coinciding with the global late Oligocene warming event, and pre-dating larger-scale faunal shifts that intensified later in the Miocene. These hypotheses will be tested using data collected from >400 m of geological section containing a diverse array of flora and fauna, with intercalated volcanic deposits providing age-constraint. Research methodologies integrate specimen-based microscopy, micro-CT techniques, morphometric and phylogenetic studies, together with geological analyses to document ecological setting and geochronology of the study sites.

por.por_cntn:
Humans live on an ever-changing landscape, and decisions on how to navigate challenges can be informed by investigating the impacts of large-scale environmental change on floras and faunas over time. The fossil and rock record of eastern Africa holds clues on how regional changes in landscape and climate have influenced biotic evolution at key intervals in Earth history. The Cenozoic Era was one such time of remarkable floral, faunal, and environmental change. Dramatic shifts occurred on the African landmass near the Paleogene-Neogene boundary, as collision between Afro-Arabia and Eurasia resulted in widespread environmental perturbation including faunal exchange. This profoundly influenced the landscape for predation and competition, resulting in expansion of some groups of animals and extinction of others.

The primate fossil record is a particularly compelling lens for exploring this topic, yet geographic and temporal knowledge gaps hinder our understanding. Against a backdrop of tectonic and faunal changes, the late Oligocene remains the least sampled interval in primate evolutionary history.

Our research teams have uncovered late Oligocene (~25-million-year-old) fossil-bearing rocks in the Nsungwe Formation of the Rukwa Rift Basin in southwestern Tanzania. We investigated fossil localities spanning a diverse array of environmental settings, deposited by rivers and marginal wetlands. Discoveries have effectively doubled the number of primate genera known from the late Oligocene interval. For example, these fossil localities have produced the earliest evidence of the divergence between Old World monkeys and apes, as well as late-surviving anthropoids and a tiny nocturnal strepsirrhine. Non-primate mammals span a significant body mass range, with tiny mouse-sized afrotherian mammals found alongside towering hippo-like anthracotheres. Other backboned animals include fishes, frogs, crocodylians, lizards and snakes, along with delicate bird specimens. Invertebrate fossils offer additional clues to faunal adaptations to tectonic and environmental shifts associated with the emergence of the East African Rift System.

Tightly linking faunal and floral diversity patterns with tectonic-mediated landform changes in the Western Branch of the East African Rift System provides a clear opportunity to link fossil discoveries with environmental settings. For example, our research team has been able to offer insight into both deep Earth magma evolution and climate processes, with additional perspectives on how large-scale mechanisms influence woodland and grassland expression, and revealing a last glimpse of Paleogene biota prior to large scale faunal turnover in the Miocene. Taking an integrated approach is necessary to test hypotheses regarding the sequence and timing of environmental and evolutionary changes.

Results have been disseminated in the US and Tanzania in various formats including conference presentations, workshops, interactive science outreach websites, exhibits, and scientific publications in international journals. Discoveries have been featured in the popular media and on websites including the National Science Foundation. Outreach efforts included K-12 school group visits to engage students in considering academic and technical careers in STEAM disciplines, with middle school and high school volunteers engaged in hands-on mechanical and digital specimen preparation. In-person and virtual laboratory tours invited elementary school audiences and the general public to interact with student and postdoctoral researchers to explore how organisms respond to environmental changes through time.

This project served in intensive hands-on research training in the laboratory/field settings for 25 undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars. US and Tanzanian students were engaged in the research project and mentored by faculty from the collaborating institutions. Five graduate students completed theses or dissertations on project topics, and 14 students and postdocs were lead or co-authors on scientific presentations and publications. Student research recruitment at the PI institution (Ohio University) was facilitated by the Program to Aid Career Exploration (PACE) program, a research internship experience focused on immersive learning for first-generation and economically disadvantaged university students in rural Appalachia. Students were recruited to engage in hands-on research on topics related to the project from a broad range of STEAM disciplines including those studying anthropology, biology, communications, computer science, education, engineering, environmental studies, fine arts, geology, history, and museum studies. Integrating multiple lines of scientific evidence to test hypotheses about primate evolution and environmental change through time, this project afforded substantial opportunities for students to interact, collaborate and learn in a multilingual and multicultural setting.
